Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.B.2.Nd.23 - Southern Vancouverian Montane & Foothill Forest EN (LC -- EN)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.B.2.Nd.23 - Southern Vancouverian Montane & Foothill Forest EN (LC -- EN)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.B.2.Nd.23 - Southern Vancouverian Montane & Foothill Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.B.2.Nd Vancouverian Cool Temperate Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Pseudotsuga menziesii var. menziesii,Sequoiadendron giganteum,Pinus monticola,Abies concolor var. lowiana,Pinus ponderosa,Pseudotsuga menziesii,
Frangula californica ssp. tomentella (= Rhamnus tomentella ssp. tomentella)
Cercocarpus montanus var. glaber (= Cercocarpus betuloides)

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Clima seco Suelos de serpentita1) Veranos muy calurosos y secos. 1) Suelo fino, rocoso, ultramáficas (gabro, peridotita, serpentinita); no siempre son rocosas; pueden ser arcilloso de hasta 76 cm de profundidad, y de arcilla pesada. Baja proporción Ca: Mg. Los suelos ultramáficos suelen ser pocos profundos y esquelético, perfil poco desarrollado, alta alcalinidad, bajas concentraciones de algunos nutrientes esenciales y capacidad de almacenamiento de agua.2) Suelo fino, rocoso, ultramáficas (gabro, peridotita, serpentinita). Los suelos en ultramáficas son generalmente poco profundos y esqueléticos, con poco desarrollo de su perfil, baja concentración de algunos nutrientes esenciales, y baja capacidad de almacenamiento de agua.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Este macrogrupo es de los bosquescubriendo el 15% del estado mas extenso de California, cubriendo mas del 15% del estado, cubre una alta gama de latitudes y elevaciones. Son bosques de piedemonte y elevaciones montañosas bajas al sur. Historicamente p´resenta incendios frecuentes de baja intensidad (aprox. cada 10-30 años). los incendios mantenian una estructura abierta pero al no presentarse se esta cerrando la estructura. 1) Estos bosques son muy variables e irregulares en su distribución, son más productivos y pueden soportar árboles de grandes tallas, aunque tienden a estar ampliamente espaciados y presentan lenta tasa de crecimiento. Las especies comunes incluyen Pseudotsuga menziesii, Pinus sabiniana, Pinus lambertiana, Pinus jeffreyi, Pinus attenuata, Lithocarpus densiflorus var. echinoides, Calocedrus decurrens, Arctostaphylos spp., Quercus vacciniifolia y Xerophyllum tenax. Hierbas perennes como Festuca idahoensis también pueden ser característicos.2) Unicamente los suelos ultramáficas con baja relación Ca:Mg pueden sorportar diferente tipo de vegetación. Bosques muy variables e irregulares en su distribución y la composición puede ser muy diversas, especialmente la de arbustos ( frecuentemente tienen bajo cubierta). Especies características: Cupressus sargentii, Pinus sabiniana, Garrya congdonii, Quercus durata, Umbellularia californica y ssp californica Frangula. tomentella (= Rhamnus tomentella ssp. tomentella). Estructuralmente, este sistema a veces tiene caracteristicas de bosque, pero también puede tener de un chaparral arborescente, lo cual depende de la historia fuego.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'California montane chaparral and woodlands'
WWF ecoregion 'Central and Southern Cascades forests'
WWF ecoregion 'California interior chaparral and woodlands'
WWF ecoregion 'California coastal sage and chaparral'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
